text: to Hong Kong after months of
anti-government protests President Trump
has urged China's leader to solve the
political crisis mr. Trump tweeted that
he had zero doubt that si Jinping could
humanely solve the problem in the
territory his comments came after
intense pro-democracy protests sparked
by an extradition bill the latest
rallies held in Hong Kong Airport to
attract global attention as well but
let's bring you up to date and take you
to our Southeast Asia correspondent
Jonathan head who joins us now from Hong
Kong
it's always difficult isn't it Jonathan
when you get these tweets from President
Trump to know what we should read into
it but what do you think its motivation
was with this tweet well I suppose Hong
Kong has been much more in the news in
the last few days simply because of a
spike in the confrontations with the
authorities an airport occupation has
brought a great deal more international
attention back at the Hong Kong and one
can only assume it's sort of wafted its
way across president Trump's radar
screen in the past most of his comments
on Hong Kong have been very
non-committal and haven't showed any
particular interest in what's going on
here suddenly he pipes up saying it
should be sold humanely we do know what
he means by that he's mentioned a
personal meeting it's not even clear who
he thinks should be meeting whom
although we assume he's offering some
kind of meeting with Xi Jinping which
and I think the Chinese were
particularly what the Americans involved
in this and sort of vaguely he's also
vaguely linked getting a free an
agreement on trade with China saying
that that should happen after Hong
Kong's resolve but at the same time his
commerce secretary Wilbur Ross has been
quoted as saying that what's going on in
Hong Kong is an entirely internal matter
of a China and there's really nothing
the US can do about it so frankly the
messaging is very mixed and in terms of
the protestors Jonathan have been shut
down at the airport but is there still a
sense of momentum
are they promising more process this
weekend what's their plan well they're
certainly planning a number of rallies
over the weekend they've already had
permission denied for one on Saturday
they're hoping for an even bigger one on
Sunday they're hoping to get huge
numbers of people out as they did early
on when these protests first began I
think
there's an understanding among the
various protest groups and they are very
fragmented remember that the scenes at
the airport on Tuesday where we actually
saw people being mobbed and attacked who
they thought were infiltrators with
flights canceled for a second day that
that perhaps has backfired on them in
terms of publicity and there was some
sympathy for among travelers but for a
set you know we met people who've been
whose flights have been delayed for a
second day who were getting a bit
frustrated and then they saw some of
this violence and we've actually seen
the protesters apologizing for that
saying that they're going to try and
learn from that with the authorities
also making it much harder for them to
get into the airport terminal so there's
no real protest going on there are a few
protesters there at the airport but no
real protest and I'm not sure if and
when they will revisit the airport
strategy but you know that they they're
very determined the lot of these young
protesters feel you know after the
failure of the umbrella movement five
years ago this is possibly their last
chance to make their anxiety about
what's happening in Hong Kong felt and
their anxiety about their lack of a
clear future and that if they give up
now they will never have another
opportunity so you know this is not over
there is still a real determination to
find ways to keep this protest movement
going
Jonathan good to see you thanks for
joining us from Hong Kong
